Award.AbstractNarration:
Virtually all flowering plants, like roses, maize, and maple trees, make pigments to color flowers, fruits, and leaves red or purple. And almost all of these red pigments are "anthocyanins" made from an amino acid called phenylalanine. There is one glaring exception to this in a group of closely related flowering plants that includes beets, cactus, and amaranthus, that don't make anthocyanins, but instead make red and yellow "betalain" pigments from the amino acid tyrosine. Like anthocyanins, betalains are important dietary antioxidants that contribute to plant and human health in many ways. This project is aimed at understanding how plant gene expression and plant cellular structures coordinate to synthesize the betalain pigments and then deliver them to the plant cell storage compartment called the vacuole. The red and yellow betalain pigments can be produced in non-betalain species, like yeast and anthocyanin producing-plants, through the expression of betalain-synthesizing genes. So it will be possible to produce modified microbes and crops with enhanced nutritional value for the benefit of people and animals. In addition, because this project is so "colorful" it is a natural draw for undergraduate students who want to pursue molecular biology and biotechnology-based careers. This project will train a cohort of 35 college freshmen each year in next-generation molecular-genetic research.


The investigators recently identified novel, betalain-biosynthetic cytochrome P450 enzymes that function to produce LDOPA and cyclo-DOPA (required intermediates) from tyrosine, and a MYB-type transcription factor that activates the genes encoding these enzymes. Remaining critical knowledge gaps include: how gene regulation impacts betalain pigment patterning and environmental response; how betalain pigments are trafficked to/across the tonoplast (vacuole membrane); why and how betalain plants avoid making anthocyanins--this mutual exclusivity being a fundamental property in this important group of plants. In this project, the beet MYB will be investigated using loss and gain of function studies to understand its network of direct and indirect targets in the beet genome. Nothing is known about how betalains are transported to the central storage vacuole. The investigators will perform inhibitor studies and tonoplast proteomic studies to test transport hypotheses, potential mechanisms, and identify associated proteins. Finally, it is not known why or how betalain accumulating plants can't or don't make anthocyanins. The tannin pathway is closely related to the anthocyanins chemically, with common intermediates up until the very last steps, and they are both regulated by versions of the combinatorial MYB-bHLH-WD transcription factor complex. Betalain accumulating plants do make tannins and the investigators will characterize the tannin pathway in developing beet seed coats, and they will attempt to recreate the anthocyanin pathway in transgenic beet roots to test hypotheses about which steps are missing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The betalain pigment pathway, leading to red and yellow pigments in beets, is restricted to a narrow group of plant taxa in the Caryophyllales order. In most families of this order, the almost ubiquitous anthocyanin pigments of other plants are replaced by betalains. The overall goal of this project is to learn more about how the betalain pigments are regulated by a transcription factor, how they are transported, and why they don?t make anthocyanins.

During the project period we used BvMYB1 Chromatin Immuno-precipitation to identify genomic DNA sequences bound by the BvMYB1 transcription factor from beet. These should represent sequences at or near genes potentially regulated by BvMYB1. We then verified that these genes were transcriptionally activated by BvMYB1 overexpression measuring the increase of mRNA of the regulated genes. These genes had been identified by our previous genetic analysis (mutations in these genes affect betalain pigment production i.e. cause red or yellow or white beets). However, we had hypothesized that we could identify a vacuole membrane pump, regulated by BvMYB1, that moves betalain pigment into the vacuole, but this was not the case. In related experiments, we identified proteins associated with the vacuole membranes of red vs. white beets. Again, the reasoning was that we would identify pumps more highly expressed on red vs. white membranes as potential betalain pumps. However, this analysis did not reveal any differentially regulated potential pumps. Work is continuing to analyze potential, but not differentially regulated, pumps using genetic approaches to knock out the potential pumps and then analyze whether this affects betalain transport. 

Beets and all betalain producing plants contain two forms of the LDOPA dioxygenase enzyme (DODA), one that transforms LDOPA to betalamic acid, required for all red and yellow betalain pigments, and one that does not. LDOPA is not a substrate for the non-betalain DODA. We hypothesized that the non-betalain pathway DODA represents the precursor enzyme and that the betalain pathway DODA evolved from that in the betalain producing lineage. Using DODA sequences from a variety of betalain producing species, we identified the amino acids that are conserved within each group but are different between the betalain and non-betalain functioning groups. Using an in vitro mutagenesis technique, we changed these key amino acids in the non-betalain DODA to match the betalain DODA. By this process we produced an "evolved" non-betalain DODA that is now able to perform the LDOPA dioxygenase reaction to produce betalamic acid. These experiments were performed in a non-betalain plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, and in brewer?s yeast. This demonstrated the probable evolutionary trajectory taken by the DODA to produce the required betalamic acid chromophore required to produce betalain pigments. This evolved DODA has seven amino acid changes. 

Another major question in betalain pigment biosynthesis was how tyrosine is hydroxylated to produce LDOPA, again a required step to make betalain pigments-what enzyme performs this function? Two molecules of LDOPA are required to make red betalains and a single LDOPA molecule is required to make yellow betalains. We showed that this step in betalain producing plants is performed by cytochrome P450 enzymes of the CYP76AD class. We showed that we had identified the correct genes by transforming non-mutated copies to express them in another non-betalain plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, along with the DODA gene discussed above. These plants were then able to produce a functional cytochrome P450 to hydroxylate tyrosine to make LDOPA and then produce the DODA enzyme to produce betalamic acid?i.e. they were able to make betalain pigments. 

Broader Impact

During each year of the project, a cohort of 35 University of Texas (UT) undergraduate researchers was supported in a Freshman Research Initiative stream allowing them to perform experiential hands-on molecular and genetic analysis of developmental pathways in plants. Also, each fall during the period, a team of UT undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students visited an Austin Independent School District elementary school to perform Science Fair workshops for students, teachers, and parents. The UT team returned in the spring semester to judge the Science Fair projects and to interview the elementary scientists about their project experiences.
